I sent you the part of the file where He said that is  was a radio, it's in=
 
the whole thing, when  I asked Him on Skype, I  couldn't understand what =
He 
was trying to say, so, i just took the first  few, the ones that made t=
he 
most sense of something on top of a monitor, your  monitor is different=
 from 
mine, mine is so skinny, only a bird can sit on it.  You probably sh=
ould 
have shown us a picture of what your monitor looked like, so  we woul=
d not have 
just tossed out other possible answers.  As I said  before, you=
r monitor 
looks like a big white box from the early 90's  to  me, or maybe=
 my eyes are 
not seeing it clearly enough. sf
 
 
In a message dated 7/14/=
2010 7:12:11 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time,  
rasterer@... writes:

 
 
=
 
Here's a way to look at your specific method.  You  say that David gave y=
ou 
the answer.  But, you were not able to hear  it, or would not accept it=
, 
until I told you what it was.  That  would sound like a frustrating situ=
ation 
for David, and you.  But,  this experiment could in theory help ther=
e, by 
making it more clear to  you when you have heard a valid message, ve=
rsus when 
you have imposed  your own prejudices into the sound (as in this=
 case, you 
said you did  not believe a radio could fit on the monitor).   =
So in your  
methodology this would be of benefit both to you (because you =
could  improve 
your skills through these experiments) and to David (as he =
would  not have to 
have you miss what he was saying as often).

--- On  We=
d, 7/14/10, SnowfireL@..., 7/14/10, <SnowfireL@...> wrote:


From: =
 SnowfireL@...<SnowfireL@...>
Subject: Re:  [EVP-ITC] Experiment 2=
0100710 - RESULTS!
To:  EVP-ITC@yahoogroupsTo: 
Date: Wednesday, July 14, 2=
010, 4:09  PM


 
Well,  the problem RJ, is all the voices that are coming =
through all the  
time, some of them are from lower levels or plains, they =
are usually  easier 
to hear, because they are closer, unless of course the=
y happen  to be tech's 
or our guides and angels.  The spirit's with  the m=
ost credibility are 
going to be harder to hear, since  they are well beyon=
d the white light, and are 
in much higher  plains.  They read our minds, a=
s they can read the minds of 
each  other, only the ones in lower plains ar=
e not able to read the minds 
of  those higher spirits if they choose to no=
t reveal themselves.   Because 
of this it's going to be tough, if I gave e=
veryone's opinion  out of the 4 
minutes, you could write a book, then when=
 I found Dave's  voice, he was not 
so easy to hear, I had to make it loude=
r, when I  tried to reach Him on 
Skype, I couldn't get what He said correc=
tly, so  it was my own fault, and not 
His. sf
 
 
In a message dated  7/14=
/2010 6:27:09 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time, 
rasterer@yahoo. com  writes:

 
=
I think it does matter though. 

One of  the things we're trying to do is s=
et up an objective framework  for 
experimenting with some of these aspects=
.  I think we  have all experienced 
the difficulty in hearing what is on s=
ome  of these recordings: sometimes 
we're not sure at first what it  says.=
 Sometimes we ask others for their 
input.  Sometimes  we only hear it once=
 someone else tells us it first.   
Sometimes we hear it wrong.  Sometimes =
we hear it right.  And so on.

It would be useful to know, as an  individua=
l, how good we are at hearing 
it right, so we have  some idea how trustwor=
thy our skill, or methods, or  
technology, is.  If we can measure that, or=
 even get a  feel for it, we can 
look for ways to improve it.  If we  can'=
t measure it, then we could be stuck. 
 

So, by  restricting the answers o=
nly to the timeframe of the  experiment, 
we can help filter out some of th=
e problems of  subjectivity: for example, 
one theory is that people can he=
ar  what they want to hear, or can these 
sounds in a certain way,  once yo=
u already know the answer.  Or, given 2 ways to  
hear a sound, being influ=
enced, even subconsciously, to hear  it one way 
over the other.  We want t=
o rule that  out.

This is one reason we can only count on answers  given d=
uring the 
timeframe.  That is when the answer is  most objective.  Once th=
e object has been 
announced, we  move into a  period where we can't discou=
nt possible  influence 
from already knowing the answer.

But, I am  confid=
ent that if a person's method or technology really can  
reveal the correct=
 answer outside the timeframe, then doing it  within the 
timeframe should =
be just as easy, and would then be  a valid objective result 
for all to se=
e.

--- On Wed,  7/14/10, SnowfireL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol.  com> wrote:

=

eriment 20100710 - RESULTS!

Date: Wednesday, =
July 14, 2010,  2:50 PM


 
it doesn't  matter, it's in the whole file, I d=
idn't think it was  possible 
to have a radio sit on top of a pc screen i  =
guess.  But, I know He did say 
it, that's all the proof  I need. haha! <G>=
 would you like the whole 4 
minute  question the whole tape?
 
 
In a mess=
age  dated 7/14/2010 5:46:11 P.M. Eastern Daylight Time,  
rasterer@yahoo. =
com writes:

 
Snowfire, as I noted at the beginning  of the test, sending =
in results 
after I already  announced what the object is can't of course b=
e part  of the 
experiment.  Someone could simply read  what I said, and it=
 could then 
influence their own  interpretation of ramdom noise, for examp=
le, or they  could 
say "I got it but forgot to mail it", or a  host of oth=
er reasons.

To make the experiment  as objective as possible, only answers=
 sent during  
the experiment's timeframe can be  valid.

4/10,  SnowfireL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol.  com> wrote:

ol. com <SnowfireL@aol.  com>

 RESULTS! [1 Attachment]

Date: Wednesday, Jul=
y  14, 2010, 2:35 PM


 
Haha,  David did get it right RJ, I just didn't se=
nd this  one in.  He 
says, Radio twice!!!  So,  cool, I didn't think he wa=
s right, but i guess, he  
was after all. sf
 
 
In a  message dated 7/14/2=
010 5:31:02 P.M. Eastern  Daylight Time, 
rasterer@yahoo. com  writes:

 

=

Snowfire, I do have more  than one monitor.  Some are in my closet  (so no=
t 
in this room, and not near me).   And the others in this room are laptop=
s.  
 None of the laptops had anything on them.   And the monitors in the c=
loset 
just have other  equipment on them.

But now that I've sent  out a p=
icture of the monitor, next time everyone  
knows what it looks like, so ma=
ybe that will  help.  Or, I'm open to 
suggestions for  other locations for=
 the object in question  too.  This was just 
close to me (I would  see it =
every day), and was also the monitor I  use for 
this newsgroup.


--- On  =
Wed, 7/14/10, SnowfireL@aol. com  <SnowfireL@aol. com> wrote:


From:  Snow=
fireL@aol. com <SnowfireL@aol.  com>
Subject: Re: [EVP-ITC] Experiment  201=
00710 - RESULTS!
To: EVP-ITC@yahoogroups  .com
Date: Wednesday, July 14, 20=
10, 2:00  PM


 
Well, RJ don't know why they couldn't get  it, maybe that =
thing doesn't  
look like a monitor to them, looks more like a  box, do you=
 have more then one 
monitor in your  house?  If David got it wrong, it was=
 my  fault for not 
understanding Him.   sf
 
 
In a message dated 7/14/201=
0 2:20:10 P.M.  Eastern Daylight Time, 
rasterer@yahoo. com  writes:

 

Th=
anks again for everyone who  participated! I admire your courage and  
moti=
vation to try different methods, see what  works, and try to improve 
every=
one's  understanding of EVP-ITC.

If you recall,  on 7/10/2010 I placed an =
object on top of my  computer 
monitor, right in front of me, and left  it =
there until today, 7/14/2010, noon 
Denver  time. The experiment was for pa=
rticipants to  determine what it was. 
Vague or partial answers  wouldn't b=
e counted (for example, just colors,  
shapes, sizes, what it's made of, et=
c): we're  looking for what it is. 
Participants could use  their ghost box=
es, EVP recorders, or I suppose  any other 
means they chose.

In order to =
 keep me honest, I took a picture of the object  at the start 
of the exper=
iment and loaded it to  the Files section (RJ folder) of this 
group. If  y=
ou can follow the link, it is here:

_http://tech.  groups.yahoo. com/group=
/ EVP-ITC/files/  RJ/RJ.20100710. 
1.zip_ (http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/gro=
up/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.zip) 

The idea was  that you could downl=
oad the file at the  beginning of the 
test, and 'keep it safe' on  your co=
mputer. Then at the end of the test, I  
would release the password so you =
could reveal  the contents of the file. That 
way, you were in  control of =
the original image during the entire  test, not 
me. 

The password for tha=
t file  is: 123BlastOff
Instructions, if you need  them, are also in that R=
J folder.

And if  you did not care to download the zip file before  the te=
st, I will 
post the final image there  too.

So to the results:

Number of=
  participants: 5
Total tries: 8
Ambiguous  answers: 0
Correct answers: 0

=
Object:  A radio
Uzipped picture:
_http://tech.  groups.yahoo. com/group/ E=
VP-ITC/files/  RJ/RJ.20100710. 
1.JPG_ (http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/=
EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.JPG) 

So what do the  results mean? All tha=
t we can really agree on  from this 
experiment is that no participant,  wi=
th whatever theories or methods or 
technology  they used, was able to corr=
ectly determine the  object. We can't say 
those theories or methods  or te=
chnologies never work. Just as we can't say  
they do. Just that, for whate=
ver reason, they  did not work this time. 
Readers can take the  results, u=
se them to improve or change their  methods, or 
keep doing what they're  d=
oing.

If anyone has any observations,  comments, or ideas for improvement,=
 let me 
know.  I hope to get a new experiment up and running  soon. Since =
there 
wasn't much participation  Mon-Wed, I think the next experiment will=
 be  
arranged to mostly span the  weekends.

Again, thanks to everyone who=
  participated in this first  experiment.

































=

                            =
    <BLOCKQUOTE                                   style=3D"BORDER-LEFT: blu=
e 2px solid"><FONT                                   style=3D"BACKGROUND-CO=
LOR: transparent"                                   color=3D#000000 size=3D=
2                                   face=3DArial><SPAN> </SPAN> 
     =
                           <DIV id=3Dygrp-text>
                           =
     <P><BR>Thanks again for everyone who 
                                =
participated! I admire your courage and 
                                mo=
tivation to try different methods, see what 
                              =
  works, and try to improve everyone's 
                                und=
erstanding of EVP-ITC.<BR><BR>If you recall, 
                             =
   on 7/10/2010 I placed an object on top of my 
                          =
      computer monitor, right in front of me, and left 
                   =
             it there until today, 7/14/2010, noon Denver 
                =
                time. The experiment was for participants to 
             =
                   determine what it was. Vague or partial answers 
       =
                         wouldn't be counted (for example, just colors, 
  =
                              shapes, sizes, what it's made of, etc): we're=
 
                                looking for what it is. Participants coul=
d use 
                                their ghost boxes, EVP recorders, or=
 I suppose 
                                any other means they chose.<BR>=
<BR>In order to 
                                keep me honest, I took a p=
icture of the object 
                                at the start of the e=
xperiment and loaded it to 
                                the Files secti=
on (RJ folder) of this group. If 
                                you can f=
ollow the link, it is here:<BR><BR><A                                   tit=
le=3Dhttp://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.zip =
                                  href=3D"http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/grou=
p/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.zip"                                   rel=
=3Dnofollow target=3D_blank>http://tech. 
                                g=
roups.yahoo. com/group/ EVP-ITC/files/ 
                                RJ/=
RJ.20100710. 1.zip</A><BR><BR>The idea was 
                               =
 that you could download the file at the 
                                b=
eginning of the test, and 'keep it safe' on 
                              =
  your computer. Then at the end of the test, I 
                          =
      would release the password so you could reveal 
                     =
           the contents of the file. That way, you were in 
               =
                 control of the original image during the entire 
         =
                       test, not me. <BR><BR>The password for that file 
  =
                              is: 123BlastOff<BR>Instructions, if you need =

                                them, are also in that RJ folder.<BR><BR>A=
nd if 
                                you did not care to download the zip=
 file before 
                                the test, I will post the fin=
al image there 
                                too.<BR><BR>So to the resul=
ts:<BR><BR>Number of 
                                participants: 5<BR>To=
tal tries: 8<BR>Ambiguous 
                                answers: 0<BR>Co=
rrect answers: 0<BR><BR>Object: 
                                A radio<BR=
>Uzipped picture:<BR><A                                   title=3Dhttp://te=
ch.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/files/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.JPG               =
                    href=3D"http://tech.groups.yahoo.com/group/EVP-ITC/file=
s/RJ/RJ.20100710.1.JPG"                                   rel=3Dnofollow ta=
rget=3D_blank>http://tech. 
                                groups.yahoo. c=
om/group/ EVP-ITC/files/ 
                                RJ/RJ.20100710. 1=
.JPG</A><BR><BR>So what do the 
                                results mea=
n? All that we can really agree on 
                                from th=
is experiment is that no participant, 
                                with=
 whatever theories or methods or technology 
                              =
  they used, was able to correctly determine the 
                         =
       object. We can't say those theories or methods 
                    =
            or technologies never work. Just as we can't say 
             =
                   they do. Just that, for whatever reason, they 
         =
                       did not work this time. Readers can take the 
      =
                          results, use them to improve or change their 
   =
                             methods, or keep doing what they're 
         =
                       doing.<BR><BR>If anyone has any observations, 
     =
                           comments, or ideas for improvement, let me know.=
 
                                I hope to get a new experiment up and run=
ning 
                                soon. Since there wasn't much partici=
pation 
                                Mon-Wed, I think the next experimen=
t will be 
                                arranged to mostly span the 
   =
                             weekends.<BR><BR>Again, thanks to everyone who=
 
                                participated in this first 
             =
                   experiment.<BR><BR></P></DIV>
